title: Glyph Balance, or Python Physics Engine applied to Type
content: I'm curious, has anyone created a python script that checks the balance of individual glyphs?
author: Jeremy Dooley

comments.content:
I am not sure about what you mean by balance but there are script which give useful data and comparison as Yanone Autopsy for Fontlab [https://github.com/davelab6/autopsy](http://web.archive.org/web/20150420170240/https:/github.com/davelab6/autopsy) and Glyphs [https://github.com/schriftgestalt/Autopsy-Plugin](http://web.archive.org/web/20150420170240/https:/github.com/schriftgestalt/Autopsy-Plugin) or Font Inspector for FontLab and Robofont [http://urtd.net/projects/fontinspector/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150420170240/http:/urtd.net/projects/fontinspector/).  
The same Yanone as also a useful tools to check visually the balance of beziers curves. It’s SpeedPunk for Robofont and Glyphs [http://www.yanone.de/typedesign/code/speedpunk/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150420170240/http:/www.yanone.de/typedesign/code/speedpunk/).  
I hope this is useful for you.
Jeremy, can you define what you mean by “balance” in this context? Like whether it leans forward or back?
